title: Neural Lyapunov Model Predictive Control: Learning Safe Global Controllers from Sub-optimal Examples

sections.iii-b neural lyapunov mpc:
The loss (10) is used to both learn V𝑉V and to tune its scaling factor in the MPC loss, α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1, to provide stability. We aim to improve the ROA of the initial controller, used to collect data, by replacing it with an MPC solving the following input-limited, state soft-constrained, optimal control problem: where x^​(i)^𝑥𝑖\hat{x}(i) and u^​(i)^𝑢𝑖\hat{u}(i) are the predicted state and the input at i𝑖i-steps in the future, s​(i)𝑠𝑖{s}(i) are slack variables, u¯={u​(i)}_​i=0N−1¯𝑢subscript𝑢𝑖_𝑖superscript0𝑁1\underline{u}=\{u(i)\}_{\_}{i=0}^{N-1}, the stage cost ℓℓ\ell is given by (3), γ∈(0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1] is a discount factor,
the function V𝑉V is
the Lyapunov NN from (9), scaled by a factor α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1 to provide stability, and x​(t)𝑥𝑡x(t) is the measured system state at the current time. The penalty ℓ_​𝕏subscriptℓ_𝕏\ell_{\_}\mathbb{X} is used for state constraint violation, see . The optimal cost is denoted as J_​MPC⋆​(x​(t))subscript𝐽_superscriptMPC⋆𝑥𝑡J_{\_}{\text{MPC}}^{\star}(x(t)). Problem (III-B) is solved online given the current state x​(t)𝑥𝑡x(t); then, the first element of the optimal control sequence, u⋆​(0)superscript𝑢⋆0u^{\star}(0), provides the action for the physical system. Then, a new state is measured, and (III-B) is again solved, in a receding horizon.
The implementation details are given in Appendix. We extend standard results from [ref]20  to the discounted case and to the λ𝜆\lambda-contractive V𝑉V from (5). In order to prove them, we make use of the uniform continuity of the model, the SQP solution and the terminal cost, V𝑉V, as done by .
Consider the candidate MPC ROA: The following are obtained for system (1) in closed loop with the MPC defined by problem (III-B). Results are stated for 𝕏_​T={0}subscript𝕏_𝑇0\mathbb{X}_{\_}T=\{0\}. For 𝕏_​T≠{0}subscript𝕏_𝑇0\mathbb{X}_{\_}T\not=\{0\}, convergence would occur to a set instead of 00. We assume V𝑉V being formally verified . Stability and robustness
Assume that V​(x)𝑉𝑥V(x) satisfies (5), with λ∈[0,1)𝜆01\lambda\in[0,1), 𝕏_​T={0}subscript𝕏_𝑇0\mathbb{X}_{\_}T=\{0\}. If N>1𝑁1N>1, μ=0𝜇0\mu=0, then the system reaches a set 𝔹_​γsubscript𝔹_𝛾\mathbb{B}_{\_}{\gamma} that is included in 𝕏_​ssubscript𝕏_𝑠\mathbb{X}_{\_}s. This set increases with decreasing discount, γ𝛾\gamma, ∀x​(0)∈Υ_​N,γ,αfor-all𝑥0subscriptΥ_𝑁𝛾𝛼\forall x(0)\in\Upsilon_{\_}{N,\gamma,\alpha}. γ=1⇒𝔹_​γ={0}𝛾1⇒subscript𝔹_𝛾0\gamma=1\Rightarrow\mathbb{B}_{\_}{\gamma}=\{0\}. If α​V​(x)𝛼𝑉𝑥\alpha V(x) is the optimal value function in 𝕏_​ssubscript𝕏_𝑠\mathbb{X}_{\_}s for the problem, μ=0𝜇0\mu=0, and if 𝒞​(𝕏_​s)≠𝕏_​s𝒞subscript𝕏_𝑠subscript𝕏_𝑠\mathcal{C}(\mathbb{X}_{\_}s)\neq\mathbb{X}_{\_}s, then the system is asymptotically stable, ∀x​(0)∈Υ_​N,γ,α⊃𝕏_​sformulae-sequencefor-all𝑥0subscriptΥ_𝑁𝛾subscript𝕏_𝑠𝛼\forall x(0)\in\Upsilon_{\_}{N,\gamma,\alpha}\supset\mathbb{X}_{\_}s. If μ=0𝜇0\mu=0, then α≥α¯𝛼¯𝛼\alpha\geq\bar{\alpha} implies that α​V​(x)≥V⋆​(x),∀x∈𝕏_​sformulae-sequence𝛼𝑉𝑥superscript𝑉⋆𝑥for-all𝑥subscript𝕏_𝑠\alpha V(x)\geq V^{\star}(x),\forall x\in\mathbb{X}_{\_}s, where V⋆superscript𝑉⋆V^{\star} is the optimal value for the infinite horizon problem with cost (3) subject to (2). The MPC has a stability margin. If the MPC uses a surrogate model satisfying (8), with one-step error bound ‖w‖_​22<μ¯2=1−λL_​V​L_​f^​x2​N​l_​ssubscriptnorm𝑤_superscript22superscript¯𝜇21𝜆subscript𝐿_𝑉subscript𝐿_^𝑓superscript𝑥2𝑁subscript𝑙_𝑠\|w\|_{\_}2^{2}<\bar{\mu}^{2}=\frac{1-\lambda}{L_{\_}VL_{\_}{\hat{f}x}^{2N}}l_{\_}s, then the system is Input-to-State (practically) Stable (ISpS) and there exists a set 𝔹_​N,γ,μ:x​(t)→𝔹_​N,γ,μ:subscript𝔹_𝑁𝛾𝜇→𝑥𝑡subscript𝔹_𝑁𝛾𝜇\mathbb{B}_{\_}{N,{\gamma},{\mu}}:\ x(t)\rightarrow\mathbb{B}_{\_}{N,{\gamma},{\mu}}, ∀x​(0)∈β​Υ_​N,γ,αfor-all𝑥0𝛽subscriptΥ_𝑁𝛾𝛼\forall x(0)\in\beta\Upsilon_{\_}{N,\gamma,\alpha}, β≤1𝛽1\beta\leq 1. Theorem 2 states that for a given horizon N𝑁N and contraction λ𝜆\lambda, one can find a minimum scaling of the Lyapunov function V𝑉V and a lower bound on the discount factor γ𝛾\gamma such that the system under the MPC has ROA Υ_​N,γ,α⊇𝕏_​ssubscript𝕏_𝑠subscriptΥ_𝑁𝛾𝛼\Upsilon_{\_}{N,\gamma,\alpha}\supseteq\mathbb{X}_{\_}s. If the model is not perfect, its error being less than μ≤μ¯𝜇¯𝜇\mu\leq\bar{\mu}, then the ROA size decreases but the system is still safe. In this case, a shorter horizon can be beneficial.
The proof of the theorem follows standard MPC arguments and is in Appendix. In order to further motivate for the search of a V𝑉V giving the largest 𝕏_​ssubscript𝕏_𝑠\mathbb{X}_{\_}s, notice that a larger 𝕏_​ssubscript𝕏_𝑠\mathbb{X}_{\_}s can allow for shortening the MPC horizon, possibly yielding the same ROA. Contrary to , we demonstrate how model mismatch and longer horizons can decrease performance with respect to an infinite-horizon oracle with same cost and perfect model. This links RL to arguments used in nominal MPC robustness  [ref]25. Let 𝐄_​𝒟​[J_​V⋆​(K⋆)]subscript𝐄_𝒟delimited-[]subscript𝐽_superscript𝑉⋆superscript𝐾⋆\mathbf{E}_{\_}\mathcal{D}[J_{\_}{V^{\star}}(K^{\star})] define the expected infinite-horizon performance of the optimal policy K⋆superscript𝐾⋆K^{\star}, evaluated by using the expected infinite-horizon performance (value function), V⋆superscript𝑉⋆V^{\star}, for the stage cost (3) and subject to (2). Similarly, let 𝐄_​x∈𝒟​[J_⋆​MPC​(x)]subscript𝐄_𝑥𝒟delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐽⋆_MPC𝑥\mathbf{E}_{\_}{x\in\mathcal{D}}[J^{\star}_{\_}{\text{MPC}}(x)] define the MPC’s expected performance with the learned V𝑉V, when a surrogate model is used and 𝐄_​x∈𝒟​[J_⋆​MPC​(x;f)]subscript𝐄_𝑥𝒟delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐽⋆_MPC𝑥𝑓\mathbf{E}_{\_}{x\in\mathcal{D}}[J^{\star}_{\_}{\text{MPC}}(x;f)] when f𝑓f is known. Performance
Assume that the value function error is bounded for all x𝑥x, namely, ‖V⋆​(x)−α​V​(x)‖_​22≤ϵsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑉⋆𝑥𝛼𝑉𝑥_superscript22italic-ϵ\|V^{\star}(x)-\alpha V(x)\|_{\_}2^{2}\leq\epsilon, and that the model error satisfies (8), for some μ>0𝜇0\mu>0.
Then, for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0: where L¯_​f=min⁡(L_​f^​x,L_​f​x)subscript¯𝐿_𝑓subscript𝐿_^𝑓𝑥subscript𝐿_𝑓𝑥\bar{L}_{\_}{f}=\min(L_{\_}{\hat{f}x},L_{\_}{{f}x}) and ψ¯¯𝜓\bar{\psi} is a 𝒦_​∞subscript𝒦_\mathcal{K}_{\_}\infty-function representing the constraint penalty terms. Theorem 3 is related to  for value-based RL. However, here we do not constrain the system and model to be stable, nor assume the MPC optimal cost to be Lipschitz. Theorem 3 shows that a discount γ𝛾\gamma or a shorter horizon N𝑁N can mitigate model errors. Since γ≪1much-less-than𝛾1\gamma\ll 1 can limit stability (Theorem 2) we opt for the shortest horizon, hence N=1𝑁1N=1, γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1. Proof of Theorem 3 is in Appendix. The stability bounds discussed in Theorem 2 can be conservative and their computation is non-trivial. Theoretically, the bigger the α𝛼\alpha the larger is the ROA (the safe region) for the MPC, up to its maximum extent. Practically, for a very high α𝛼\alpha, the MPC solver may not converge due to ill-conditioning.
Initially, by using the tool from [ref]27 within an SQP scheme, we tried to tune the parameters through gradient-based optimization of the loss (10). These attempts were not successful, as expected from the considerations in . Therefore, for practical reasons, in this work we perform a grid search over the MPC parameter α𝛼\alpha. Note that the discount factor γ𝛾\gamma is mainly introduced for Theorem 3 and analysed in Theorem 2 to allow for future combination of stable MPC with value iteration.
